147743973.review:
This is one of my top 3 loved games on Steam.  The graphical style, some elements of gameplay, and a few enemies were heavily influenced by Castlevania: SOTN. The music for the first zone, as well as the ending, are pretty banger.  Run around and slap at things with your sword and use [strike]hearts[/strike] mana to throw axes, knives, etc. at foes.  Die a lot.  

With a variety of classes to choose from, you can pick what fits your playstyle (out of 3-6 choices, depending on your progress).  The barbarian queen/king is my favorite, with their huge HP pool and shout ability to blast away enemies and projectiles.  You can customize your loadout with equipment and runes, which theoretically you could swap in and out for different classes, but I find myself always using the same loadout for every class.  There is an Architect NPC, but frankly I found them useless.

Around New Game +3, the game starts to fall apart because there is nothing to do with your gold.  This results in either a) collecting gold, only to give it to Charon  b) leaving tons of gold and diamonds on the floor all over the castle, which feels weird.  Thankfully, in the sequel they fixed this.

On subsequent runs, clearing the entire castle takes slightly over an hour if you survive it.  Originally I played this to New Game +23 where I would die in 1-3 hits, so farming stat ups became almost impossible.  However, since then they patched the game to make the stat up chests scale with NG+ (i.e. instead of a health max up always giving +5, now it gives +10, +15, .. +85, based on your NG+ count.  Starting with a fresh file recently, I'm back to the NG teens, and it seems impossible to die.  Probably the stat ups scaling is a bit too high.

One other gripe - one of the possibilities from stat up treasure chests is 'weight' increase.  This is useful early on for helping you equip better gear.  However, at some point you reach a cap where you could equip all the heaviest gear (if you even wanted to; I use some gear which is lighter for other stats I prefer).  Meaning, when you are going through the castle for essentially just farming stat ups and seeing how high NG+ you can go, you occasionally will get this weight option which is now useless.  It would have been nice, especially before they added stat scaling, if weight was removed from the drop pool once you reach a certain number (600 or so?).

Enemies physically get larger as you upgrade your castle, until the point they are stupidly big in my opinion.  A few ranged enemies can easily make the screen a bullet hell.. I wish the projectiles were toned down a bit.

It may sound like I have many complaints, but I think the longer you play a game, the more the bad parts stand out.  Still, as I said, it is one of my top 3 loved games on Steam, and it is definitely worth my time.

147376564.review:
If you see my play time increasing its because I am going to finish this game out of a personal vendetta.

Let me make abundantly clear, this game has [b]NO[/b] respect for you, for your time, or for your effort. There are no "Oh, I see what I could have done differently there." moments, there are no "Ah, I see how that killed me." moments, and there are no "Ah, I feel stronger now" moments. I'll cover each aspect and why I feel the way I do. I will also add the disclaimer that I'm generally not a fan of action platformers, but I did my best to separate that from this review.

[h2]PROGRESSION[/h2]
Progression is existent, and feels like what you'd see in a modern day mobile game. It, is, [b]SLOW[/b], as in having an amazing run will maybe get you 3 to 4 low cost upgrades, this is in a game where the base health and mana can be upgraded [b]75 TIMES!!!!!![/b] This results in upgrades feeling unimpactful and unsatisfying. The other forms of progression are sword and armor upgrades and sword and armor runes. Runes are limited to one per slot (5 in total), and armor is limited by your weight (another stat that you need to upgrade), both of which costs shocking amounts of gold and get more expensive as you by more. Nothing you will do within the progression system will make you feel stronger, it will just make you slightly less likely to die in the first three rooms... Speaking of which...

[h2]THE ROOMS[/h2]
Room designs vary wildly, from actually quite good to absolute crap. Biggest problem many of these rooms face is that you have to blindly fall before you see where you can land (often surrounded by high damage spikes). There are rooms where there are spikes on the ceiling and you need to fit through a gap nearly the same size as you. And enemy layouts are often designed not to be challenging, but outright disrespectful to the player.

[h2]THE ENEMIES[/h2]
The enemies are some of the most inconsistent, and poorly designed I've seen in a game. Firstly, all but a select few enemies have hurt boxes on their bodies, some of which make sense as that is their way of attacking, other such as armored guards or floating Wizards make no sense at all. Enemies hit like a British dad after their football team loses, and have inconsistent health. Usually there is a clear indicator of when an enemy gets stronger, such as an new area or stage, in this game their strength varies from room to room. Hitboxes feel inconsistent and attack patterns have all the consistency of the Washington Nationals (none to speak of).

[h2]CONTROLS[/h2]
Shit. Absolute. Shit. Your character feels incredibly floaty, anything short of a short hop or full jump feels incredibly inconsistent, there is no "coyote time", which makes the game insanely hard to control. Attacking feels inconstant, dodging is incredibly hard,  for basic enemies and attacks because of the controls, and attacking feels weird because of how the character need to move a little before they turn around. Overall the game does NOT control well.

[h2]FINAL THOUGHTS[/h2]
This game aged like fine milk, and I cannot, in 2023, recommend playing it. The difficulty does not come from a fair place, it comes from the combination of every bad design aspect in this game. I'm not a fan of Dark Souls, and I'm HORRIBLE at it, but I would still recommend it because its difficultly comes from a place where it can be conquered, This game's difficulty comes from a lack of respect for the player.

At first glance, it is a promising concept; however, the game really falls flat. The random attributes for progeny are a simple addition that doesn't really add anything. The difficulty stems from the clunky controls that make bullet hells and messy rooms with traps difficult to navigate. The hitboxes for attacks are broken (and this is not my own experience, this is a known problem in the game). The gameplay loop isn't enjoyable. Most deaths feel unfair and undeserved; rarely achieving any real progression you'd expect in a "roguelite" except in the few cases where you managed to get enough gold to increase your HP by a measly +10 points.

I've read many reviews by now that share the same experience as me:
Start a game, play for 3-4 hours die a lot of times, improve your character marginally and uninstall. Repeat a few times over the course of years.

The game simply isn't that good, or at least, the controls sure make it hard to enjoy. I don't believe it's fair to ask people to ignore glaring issues with the game just so they can maybe enjoy it for the last 3 hours of gameplay. The problems with the game are obvious once you look at the stats in HowLongToBeat. 11% of players start the game and never finish it. It takes a median 16.5 hours of dying over and over while improving your character marginally every few deaths to finish the game. Perhaps after many hours of practice you could master it, get used to the shitty controls and enjoy it; I'm simply not sticking around for that.

I believe this game achieved the recognition it has because it firmly established the idea for a modern roguelite back in 2013; but, it's definitively a rather early, crude and primitive attempt at a 2D platforming roguelite. There're better roguelikes out there to spend your time playing. I hope Rogue Legacy 2 will be more refined.

I don't actually recommend playing this game anymore, as the sequel - from what I've seen - fixes every issue I have with it.

However, to ignore the (pardon the pun) legacy of this game would be dismissing the advances it made to the genre. It came out almost a decade ago, when the roguelite scene was still nascent; the original Isaac was only two years old, and Risk of Rain would release later that year. It was the first game to really nail a sense of proper progression; even runs that go poorly might be able to advance something in the metagame, and every step along the way was an actual improvement (contrasting, say, Isaac, where some runs would succeed only to unlock a bad item.)

it made those strides with some hiccups, though.  The knowledge base for the game is relatively small, as all of your characters have the exact same melee attack and one of 11 spells, most of which are barely useful. There aren't many enemy varieties, with the only area having mostly unique ones being the Forest. The bosses are fairly typical 2D-platformer bullet hell, but unfortunately controls feel slippery and janky due to movement being purely digital. It takes some practice to dodge those patterns, and it never feels good.

The last achievement - one where you clear the entire game in under 15 deaths - also feels completely counter-intuitive to the game's design. You're supposed to die early on, not just because you lack knowledge but because the game scales harder than your characters do at the start. There's a reason why the speedruns rush Shinobi ASAP: it's the only class that can deal enough damage early game. I barely eked it out with 14 deaths, and most of those were Shinobi.

TL;DR Was a good game in 2013, but play the sequel instead.

Read the FULL (steam has a limit on characters) review here: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/rogue-legacy---a-review

 Hello everyone, I am the roguish G.E.M.Simov, a knight errant, here to tell you that Rogue Legacy had good ideas, and was good in concept, but then in practice it turned out to be dour.

Gameplay

 This one is going to be a bit wordier than the ones I usually put out, which might have something to do with the fact that I really like Rogue Legacy, whilst at the same time I really dislike it. In a sense, it feels as if it is a very primeval, maybe even primordial attempt at doing a roguelike/roguelite - which is very nice, but also brings with it great deals of sorrow.

 Conceptually - very good! Actually, however, it is not, due to a number of reasons.

 Reason number one: CONTACT DAMAGE!

 Other issues with the gameplay. The Player gains access to a ‘dash’ move quite early on in the game. Unfortunately, this dash move does not provide the player with ‘invincibility’ frames, unlike the ‘dodge roll’ from Dark Souls (which came out in 2011 and is said to have influenced the developers of Rogue Legacy). One could argue that giving the dash invincibility frames would be very counterproductive, as it would trivialize the game…

 But there’s already a dash which gives the PC invincibility frames IN the game. Enter the ‘shinobi’, or rather the ‘hokage’ class, who comes with the special ability of having the highest strength in the game and doing massive damage with every hit, whilst also having the ability to dash… But with invincibility frames. It is literally the same as the dash the Player has on their disposal, but instead of going through (instead of movement) it features a ‘blink’. The PC is teleported to their destination, and thus can go through enemies.

 Does that make the ‘hokage’ the best class? Well, no, what makes them the best class would be their obscene strength stat. In fact, it is incredibly trivial. Sure, it might require 5 mana per cast, but that’s such a tiny amount that it barely matters.

 THEN there’s another problem. The consistency of the game keeps going to the toilet and flushing itself down the drain. Invincibility frames - we don’t want those! Except when Zombies pop up from the ground and hit you and damage you while being impossible to damage, that’s okay. The Zombies can have invincibility frames and they can hit you!

 The issues don’t stop there, but I have the feeling that through the violent dismembering of the game that I am currently performing you, dear reader, can tell that there’s something very intriguing about it. After all, I’ve gone and gotten that in-depth on a game I’m supposedly lampooning. That is something very intriguing, and it is bound to the supposed ‘having no fun’ period I mentioned earlier.

 All this game’s problems pile on and combine into a beast of unmatched dimensions, a beast so foul and unpleasant that I don’t want to deal with it. Sure, I did eventually deal with the ‘uber’ bosses, I did fight ‘the brothers’ in NG+2, but was it fun? No. Well, it was amusing, because these fights are almost completely disconnected from what the game actually is and present something totally outlandish.

 The boss-fights in this are good. The mini-boss fights - not so much, but the boss fights are decently good. They do require stupendous amounts of trial and error, which annoyed me, but they were well done.

 I’ll stop here, though. I could have mentioned equipment, and how it’s both super strange and wonky, as well as needlessly hard to come by, and how it’s also stupendously useful, but I feel as though its issues come from the rest of the issues I’ve outlined. I mentioned runes only in passing, but that’s because they’re barely interesting.

 Yes, you do get to have contact damage, but it sucks and doesn’t fix the problem I spoke of. Yes, you do get extra gold, yes you do get healing and mana back, you get stuff, but nothing makes your shitty attacks better, so just eat it.

 I really like Rogue Legacy on a conceptual level. I want to like it on a practical level, too, but I don’t. 2/3

Presentation

 Cellar Door Games have done an impressively good job with making this game look the way that it does. It looks good. It looks as though it is its own thing. I’ll easily recognize the silly sword of the PC, I’ll know I’m looking at Rogue Legacy if I see any screenshot from the game.

 The music is also kinda okay, even if I found it a bit… Lackluster, I suppose. Or maybe not my cup of tea.

 The way the tutorial is done is not bad at all, and it is presented in a manner that is relevant to the story, as well. In fact, the presentation of this game might be its strongest suit, which is most intriguing.

 That’s owed up to the concept of quirks I mentioned earlier, in the Gameplay section. Each character the Player gets to play is very likely to have at least one quirk. These quirks can slightly alter gameplay, but what they mostly do, and what I like about them, is that they alter the way the game looks. One character might see everything in black and white, another might see things in sepia, one might be short-sighted, making everything beyond a certain radius blurry, whilst another might be far-sighted, making everything within a certain radius blurry.

 A character might have a condition where they curse and swear whenever they’re hit, or a character might have glaucoma and have everything outside of a certain radius be darkened, nigh imperceptible. A character might have dementia and might see enemies that aren’t actually there, who can’t be hit nor can they hit the character.

 Those are stupendously interesting, and the most intriguing one of them would be ‘the One’, which turns everything into NEON! It’s so neat…

 But that isn’t where it ends. This game is filled with references which I found quite endearing, quite pleasant. One would be that to ‘The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim’, another would be to ‘Naruto’, a third would be to ‘World Of Warcraft’ (at least I think it was such).

 Admittedly I think I may have a weakness for pixel-art. Additionally, I might have a weakness for fantasy. Those, then, coupled, make for a very compelling, in my eyes, visual or even simply conceptual experience. I’ve nothing to complain about in relation to the Presentation of the game. 3/3

Story

 This is it. The weakest part of the game. It’s weakest because it is made up of around 25 half pages worth of text. There is an interesting little twist at the end, but everything is so bare-bones that it barely matters.

 I liked the way the 25 half pages were written. I liked the way it presented the character writing them going through the motions they were going through. I liked the reasoning behind their actions, I liked the logic to it.

 Unfortunately, that’s all there’s to it. There was no interaction. When the Player recruits, say, the Enchantress, she presents a story detailing why it is that her current situation is as it is, she asks for the PC’s help… And then that’s that. Even if the Player brings her everything she has once lost, she does not say anything ever again, she does not react.

 Every single ‘helpful’ character is like that. They’re all extremely limited and barely characters. The only exception might be Charon, who is so wreathed in mystery that there’s barely any character to be had, but then the clown and the miserly elf are also as mysterious and unknown as Charon, yet they’re far worse in the sense that the mystery does not make sense.

 In fact, very little in this game makes sense, story-wise. It isn’t a game meant to be experienced for its story, and the story - the lore - is not even really meant to be considered. 1/3

Legendary Point

0/1

Conclusion
6/10. It’s a game that could be called slightly above average, but only slightly so. Tentative recommendation.

This is my 3rd attempt at a review of Rogue Legacy so my thoughts and feelings for the title are a bit complicated. On one hand I enjoy the art style quite a bit, the controls are responsive enough, and you unlock a double jump early in the game. I like that the castle layout is different every time, kind of, it's good and bad. It's good because you'll be playing the first part of the castle over and over and over again to level up, but the bad thing is because it's always changing I don't feel like I'm getting better or progressing at all. And the pace of progression is what leads me to not be able to recommend this game. You see, I'm a complete masochist so even though I hate tedious grinding to level up I still do it for some sick self loathing reason but I know the vast majority of gamers wouldn't enjoy it. Then how do I explain the "very positive" status of this title? Well, that's because I whole heartedly suck at video games. I don't play games to beat them, I play games to enjoy the new experience, to discover and uncover, then eventually I hit the limit of my abilities and say "okay funs over time to buy a new game", so I'm not going to sit here and say "this game is too hard" because the majority of people who play it don't feel that way so obviously it's me who finds it too hard, not everyone. The one thing that I have a hard time accepting is that people aren't turned off by how slowly you level up in this game. I've leveled up my magic/health, I've upgraded several character types, I've purchased all the armor and equipped a bunch of runes and after all that I don't feel like my character is any stronger than I was in the very beginning. A lot of that has to do with the fact that you can never play as the same character twice in a row so I can't get used to any abilities or traits, that's something I would rather not deal with but whatever, it's part of the game and there's no getting aroudn it.

TL:DR version: I bought this title while it was on sale, a very generous discount, and that's what I suggest you do as well if you're interested in checking this game out, otherwise I personally would not buy it or recommend buying it at full price.

Could I start over from scratch for an 'easier' time, erasing 30 hours of essentially just grinding? Sure. But why? Not only why from a reasonable standpoint, but why from a development standpoint was this basically forced, unbeknownst, on players looking to 100%?

As a product of its era, maybe it was good. Not anymore.

This is considered one of the pioneers of modern roguelite genre. And there are two kinds of pioneers: those who hold up to successors, and those that only pale as more time goes. This is the later. I'd even argue it embodies the worst of roguelites - you need to grind up and progress to enjoy the game, and even then it remains basic.

General premise is this - your family is cursed and each generation must carry on the duty of conquering a castle by defeating it's bosses. You get some family manor upgrades unlocking new options and stat boosts but everything boils down to a selection of successors to take your place. They mostly differ in class (which you unlock more of as you play and collect money) and traits, which are as often comically gimmicky as mechanical. Too many of gimmicky are either frustrating or one off jokes that get boring fast.You try to beat bosses but also collect gold for upgrades. Big issue with upgrades is how many of them are the +10 health incremental, unimaginative increases. And it takes a lot of skill and time to beat game with base stats so you'll have to spend a lot grinding your way up.

If you are into exploring rougelites as a genre and want to familiarize with earlier ones, maybe consider Spelunky, it holds up so much better. Or Bindinf of Isaac, maybe.

I want to be clear at the outset -- there are a lot of good things about Rogue Legacy.

Rogue Legacy is extremely polished. It offers snappy action and clean, responsive controls. It offers numerous progression paths that each provide different degrees of customization, from upgrading gear slots, to unlocking additional runes, to increasing base stats, to adding classes to the pool of possible options each time a new character is rolled. All of this is very good (in my opinion).

I have a neutral stance toward the heir "trait" system, wherein each time a character dies, a new heir is chosen who comes with a number of characteristics or traits that can have anywhere from extremely benign or irrelevant impacts to being completely game redefining. While some of the effects could be classified as "cute," having the entire map turned upside down for one run always ends up feeling obnoxious to me. Sometimes, a given attempt arbitrarily becomes a challenge run because you didn't have a better choice of next heir. 

Conceptually, I'm neutral toward the entire notion, but I do have a negative reaction to how defining some of the characteristics can be, like having a massively bigger or smaller hitbox on your character. The game doesn't take itself seriously, and this mechanic (like many other things in the title) borders on the ridiculous, and yet the game is hardly a pushover. Indeed, it will most likely take a normal player a great many attempts to build up the gold and resources to conquer the dungeon, as the game is very deliberately set up to allow the accumulation of power over time (that's one of the selling points, after all). There's a tonal dissonance there, and I experience that with the game's wildly fluctuating difficulty where you have relatively little control over who your next character will be and what advantages or disadvantages they'll bring. That could be seen as its own little minigame (how far can I get each time using the random nonsense the game threw at me), but I'd rather challenge myself when I want to challenge myself, and improve at the classes and abilities I like when I want to. The randomness here doesn't feel like it adds a lot, and instead just leaves me liking the good aspects of the game less.

So if I don't like the core gimmick, why did I spend all this time playing it?

Rogue Legacy is still fun. It's just not as fun as it could be. It works against itself and has tonal dissonance between mechanics and presentation (this is obviously purely to taste; one could say the same of Cuphead but I have zero complaints about Cuphead). I think it could be argued that I am taking a fun, lighthearted experience and attaching way too much weight to my issues -- and someone arguing that would almost certainly be right.

At the end of the day, though, there's something about Rogue Legacy that still rubs me the wrong way. I have fun in the moment, but there's always a bitter aftertaste/afterthought that leaves me mulling over what could have been better. For the price tag, I think one can easily do better.

First of all, it was hard to decide on give this game a thumbs down, I wish Steam had a "Mixed" option

As you probably know, Rogue Legacy is a roguelite game, you go through a randomly generated castle, get coins to buy upgrades that makes you more powerful so you can have an easier time

Yes, the game is very hard in the beginning, and the clunky controls don't help. But as you play, learn how enemies behave and stop rushing head-first into danger, you will start getting more gold to upgrade your character and the game feels a lot less bullshit

But the biggest problem of this game is the system itself, upgrades become too expensive too fast, to the point that playing the game "normally" and getting upgrades feels more like a chore than fun. You are forced into speedrunning your way to chests because they give you much more gold than killing enemies, all of that to upgrade your Attack Up once or twice per run

Still with all the complaints and nitpicks above I want to say this is still an addictive game play loop and process. Good game.  Worth your money and time on sale.

TL;DR, just play Dead Cells if you want a side-scrolling roguelike.

While This game isn't terrible, I'd give it maybe 6/10, it isn't what I hoped it would be. The gameplay felt clunky to me, the grinding felt REALLY bad, and some of the time you lose because you don't get a good class. At least in my experience.

The humor isn't good, and while the game was difficult, instead of getting better, you can just grind out money. I also felt it was a weird decision to make it so you can only beat each boss EXACTLY once. If you beat a boss on a run, it stays dead until you beat the final boss. Hardly something I'd expect to see from a roguelike. And when you beat the final boss, you get forced into newgame+ which swaps all the early game enemies with late game ones and gives them boosted stats. I gave up due to not wanting to grind and having already beaten it once.

It is kinda hard to explain why this game left a bad taste in my mouth. I think part of the problem was that magic felt not only weak but hard to play around, and most of the time the random magic your character gets is the only one you will get. Top that off with every class playing the same way more or less, all of them get a sword and the only thing different is the stat spread, which you can offset through grinding anyway. Out of the classes the only 3 I felt were actually any good were The Paladin, The Hokage, and The Spelunker. And the latter one was just to make the grind less bad.

No hate on the developers btw, I loved Full Metal Furies. However, I probably won't try out Rogue Legacy 2, at least not until its full release.

108392311.review:
I know people don't like to read walls of text so I will try to make this not a wall of text for Rogue Legacy.

Pros
1-Cartoony, lighter side version of Ghosts 'N' Goblins
2-Very addicting action platformer
3-Great variety of music that can be changed from finding a Jukebox in the levels.
4-Interesting concept of "leveling up" as you unlock new parts of your Manor.
5-You can choose from up to 3 different characters with random traits and abilities every life.
6-Some of the funniest dialogue I have seen in games in years with a sample here below:

"I still have not heard a response from the rock I tossed in earlier...
...On a side note, I am now using the forest fissure as my own personal lavatory.  I wonder if I am pooping into another dimension..."

Cons
1-Can be frustrating at times while trying to dodge many different projectiles from enemies.
2-If you forget to use the Architect to lock a level down so you can continue to go through it to get more loot, then you lose out on a favorite design for that playthrough.
3-The above mentioned Architect charges you a flat 40% of all Gold you earn on that life, which if you are not raking in lots of Gold it will feel like you are getting very little value in terms of finding lots of Gold.
4-Bosses and Mini-Bosses are larger, more powerful, faster, often in groups, with more abilities, and with more health than their standard counterparts as regular enemies.
5-As your health gets lower closer to you dying you lose strength in your attacks and it takes more hits to kill enemies.

However, considering these Cons I still would recommend Rogue Legacy to people.  I give this game a 5/5.

Thank you for reading my review and God bless you all.

TL;DR-
Gameplay: 8/10
Story and Characters: 4/10
Writing and Dialogue: 5/10
Graphics: 8/10
Music & Sound: 9/10
Replayability: 9/10
Length: 7/10
A game where doing essentially the same thing over and over is, oddly enough, a good thing: Inspirational Insanity/10

-REVIEW-

Remember back in the days when dying in a video game sucked? In games as far back as the NES, you’d run out of lives and have to start the whole thing over, as devs back then had no idea that arcade strategies didn’t translate well to home consoles. Nowadays dying isn’t quite so harsh, but you’d lose progress regardless, doubly so if you hadn’t saved in a while.

In Rogue Legacy, however, dying is GOOD!…I guess. Probably depends on how strong your sense of pride is. Regardless, when the health bar drops to zero, the game is NOT over. Rather, the game continues as you pick a new toon and, with the funds you collected prior, improve your stats and powers. Sounds pretty awesome, right?

Well…it actually is! It’s not a pleasure cruise, as a good deal of randomness is involved, and the difficulty ramps up fairly quickly as you advance, but in my opinion, it’s a clever sort of endurance test: fight until you die, spend your winnings on upgrades, then roll up your sleeves and die, die again. I’ll tell you right off the bat that anyone who doesn’t like the idea of dying constantly will likely not enjoy it, whereas those who love the idea of adapting to constantly shifting gameplay will definitely feel at home here.

So let’s start with the story. The game actually begins with a sort of prologue-esque level where you control a knight in a tutorial level, where said knight completes his mission by succeeding the king in a manner not unlike how Arthas succeeded his father in Warcraft 3. After that, you time skip for about, um, er…*checks notes* Ok, so time skips are never detailed, so you become Sir Lee, the first of many, many heirs who will go through the castle, slaughtering foes, grabbing coins, obtaining an occasional power-up, and even playing a carnival game or two(no, that’s not a joke), all while wondering how this castle sits atop what appears to be an outpost of hell and isn’t being overrun by demons. Oh, right, the story…well, there’s a few journal entries about some jerkwad hoping to gain a bunch of power(likely the guy you played as in the tutorial), and that’s basically it. That’s right-you’re going after four evil masters of great and terrible power, killing them all to open the big door at the front of the castle, and ultimately going after the BBEG because…hey, it’s a game, it’s what you do! Yeah, not much of a narrative incentive to get through the game, though to be fair, I have yet to see any rogue-like have a story that goes above and beyond “you’re the hero, now go kill stuff” routine.

Thankfully, the gameplay makes up for it a good deal. In fact, this was the first real roguelike I ever played, and I got a great first impression. The idea of starting off, using your own skills to see how far you can get before you hit the inevitable wall, then taking what you earned, beefing yourself up, and seeing how much farther you get is a cool way of shoving aside the idea that dying is always bad, boo hoo(it can still be frustrating if it happens too frequently). Better yet, this isn’t one of those games where you’re just handed stuff to get you way farther just because you bit it. This game is very challenging, especially when you go into the biomes past the castle, and plenty of skill is demanded. That’s not to say the challenge is indomitable; the strong variety of enemies give you plenty to watch out for, but they have fairly recognizable patterns that are easy to recognize, if not avoid 100% of the time.

Of course, a roguelike can’t just have every run be the exact same(unless you found a playstyle that can destroy the game *rolls eyes*), so every time you fall off the ramparts, you’re given a random selection of three heirs; each with a different class that gives differing amounts of health and mana(and in one case, the value of gold you find), a different magic power or two, and even a special ability if you upgrade the class via upgrades. Now as awesome as this is, each class does have the exact same rudimentary playstyle barring alterations(you hit stuff with a sword, basically), so aside from powers and traits, each class is basically the same, which feels a bit jarring if you’ve played other medieval fantasy stuff(BWAH? The mage wears PLATE MAIL?!).

Since I mentioned it, each class also has various traits, all of which can impact the game in some way, be they beneficial, detrimental, or just there for the lolz. These traits can definitely shake things up, and as such, require a bit of adapting, though they can provide some fun little misadventures(i.e. heirs with dwarfism can fit in tiny passages).

Finally, there’s the acquisition of equipment and runes; basically weapons, armor, and trinkets that can provide various upgrades and give you a useful edge in certain scenarios. Of course, the game doesn’t want you getting too powerful, so there are limits as to what you can have, although said limits can get boosted in the upgrades section, so there you go.

I suppose the one downside to the game is the fact that it’s essentially RNG: The Game. I get that RNG is the point, as rearranging the castle, giving you different heirs, and outfitting them with ever changing traits and such, but let’s face it: sooner or later there will be one of THOSE runs where, even with all the progress they’ve made, players will eventually run into a situation where they get hit by some bad moments, whether they have classes that aren’t as good as the others(if you don’t care about crit rates, DON’T choose the assassin), have only negative traits to choose from(or at least no positive ones), or worst of all, go through a castle, run into a chance to open a fairy chest(primary rune source), all of which require some trial, and yet your character is completely unable to do them(i.e. they may require dwarfism or an invincibility power). This isn’t game breaking in the least, but it can definitely get annoying at times, especially if there’s that one rune you really want. There is an npc at the camp that can lock down a castle layout in exchange for a share of the profits you find, but even that doesn’t eliminate all the RNG. In the end, while I do find adaptability a fun challenge, the fact that you have little control over what you adapt to can sour things, especially knowing that you have to explore a good chunk of the area ALL OVER AGAIN if you don’t want to give money to the castle lockdown service, especially if you’re ready to hunt a boss.

Graphics and sound wise, I was rather hooked by the more bit-style appearance and occasional chiptune bits mixed into the nice and varied music tracks that accompany your adventure. As someone who grew up with the NES and such, I enjoyed the auditory and visual nostalgia that the game provided. It stands out without being overly distracting, and I liked it.

So if you’re one of those players who hates getting nothing out of dying, or bashing your head against a game repeatedly, definitely give this game a run. It may be a bit dated, what with a sequel in early access, but the overall fair challenge, the class and trait combinations, occasionally powerful or hilarious, and the look and feel of it all make the game something you may come back to again and again, which is good, especially if you want to win. Thanks for reading!

101568753.review:
Rogue Legacy is one of the many roguelikes that tried to make a name for themselves in the early 2010's. Its a really basic game and a relatively basic roguelike. But it has 2 big things that it did that other roguelikes did not. 

First of all is its trait system, every death gives you a completely new character with new weird quirks both positive and negative, its a fun novelty and at the time it was really cool. The problem is eventually this becomes frustrating and annoying, some traits are so bad you would rather reset a run instead of playing with it.

The second of its twists is the main hub. You build up a massive castle that provides you many benefits, that way even if you die many many many times you can still slowly build up your characters and get stronger. For the time this was kind of revolutionary, most roguelikes seem to have something like this nowadays but at the time it was all about starting from a really basic starting point and just rolling with it. Rogue Legacy in that regard was one of the first popular roguelikes to really implement this mechanic in the way we see it today.

Now this on paper sounds great, the problem is the game is balanced around the main hub mechanic, this means that it can take a LOT of grinding before you are strong enough to move onto the next part of the game. It becomes very quickly very repetitive to just grind for money, die, buy some new power up and keep going. The dungeon you go through is also surprisingly consistent, even if its all randomized there are a set number of rooms that usually will appear. Enemies are the same for each area and the boss is the same for each area. As a result you get a roguelike that feels less random and a lot more basic.

This makes it one of the simplest mechanical roguelikes out there, it can be a lot of fun but it usually burns itself out quite quickly over time. The early parts of it are very exciting and fun, but the more you play the more you feel like you are just replaying the same like 20 minutes over and over again. For the price you are still getting a great experience. I enjoyed my experience with it and got a good amount of time out of it, and even with it being a bit outdated I still think its a great game to go back to and enjoy from time to time.

Still alive? Worry not, successive clears through the game can make the castle harder and harder until you eventually die. Which takes me onto my next point; Death.

Now not only do they have a number of unique traits that boost combatitive stats, but this company really show their sense of humour, with a wave of stats that are 'miscellaneous' and just downright funny. [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/tldreview/discussions/5/3052862273799490584/]I wrote too many words for Steam to display, so here's the full review.[/url]

[h1]What Worked For Me[/h1]
I like the relative sense of humor the game has. Sending countless generations of your family to their likely deaths is pretty grim, but it's never painted as a dark affair. I mean, you do have the long, long lineage screen you can look at, but there's no bloodshed (other than what the eyeball monsters shoot at you) and death is a pretty clean affair--everything but your character fades to black, your character clutches their chest, drops their sword, and keels over. Their ghost rises out of their body and turns into a portrait. Womp womp. The game isn't exactly silly (all the time, anyway) too, so that really does soften the blow of how dark the goings-on really could be. 

Each class does play differently from the next. Almost all of them have a STR penalty, but they're boosted in some other way. You won't completely change how you play from one class to the next since most of them will need to hit things with their swords, but the mage types will get better use out of spells and be able to use them more often, for example. It's a little like Broforce in that you need to adapt to what you're given when your previous guy dies, though you have a choice instead of having a new hero being picked at random. 

Though leveling is different than most RPGs, you still can feel that you get stronger with more upgrades. Enemies that gave you trouble earlier become effortless targets later on, and they're still worth fighting for their gold! It's too bad you can't re-fight old bosses without a New Game Plus loop. It'd be really cool to see how badly you struggled against Khidr at the start and how different it is with your level of power at the end. 

[h1]What I Didn't Like[/h1]
The layers of RNG with respect to gear and runes. I mentioned it earlier, but what if you wanted to mimic my strategy with the final boss? "Get a Grace Rune." So you'd have to go find a Fairy Chest (I didn't take a Miner, so it's a crapshoot where they are), then complete the challenge ('No Jumping'? Guess I'm coming back with a Dragon), and then it might not be the right rune at all (Not another Siphon!). And [i]then[/i] it might be for the 'wrong' slot (I can take Grace, or I can double jump...hmm...). I can tolerate then having to buy the rune to use it given how everything else is money-driven, but even if you are diligent with scouring the castle, you still might not end up with something useful. 

Speaking of RNG, you can always be dealt a pretty bad selection of heirs. That's just how the game goes, I know. There's an upgrade to reroll your selections once, but you lose the last 'hand' you're dealt, so there's no guarantee your new hand will be better. If you really like a certain class playstyle, you won't always be able to play it. 

Hmm, third thing... I guess I'll say that the final boss gave me a pretty sizable amount of trouble to the point where I got discouraged to keep playing. I saw a lot of grinding in my future to get more upgrades that would ultimately not be enough, so back to the gold mines. I, uh, actually looked up if Grace Runes worked on bosses, so that definitely gave me the help I needed. The fourth boss was a wall for a while too, but I'll again admit that I'm not very good at this game. And that someone finished with zero damage taken at all. 

[h1]Verdict - 4/5[/h1]
It's pretty good. I couldn't stomach playing it for very long, maybe two or three runs at a time, but I think not having anything else lined up to act as a chaser didn't help me. And I hit a serious low point right before the end that had me ready to give this game a three. If you like the idea of metaprogression as opposed to a traditional roguelike starting you back at zero with nothing you did the last game having an impact on the next, then this platformer might be interesting. 

And honestly, I played the demo and preordered this game so long ago. It, uh, just took me a long time to get back to it. I may not have enjoyed it nearly as much as the initial interest and hype would've led me to think I would, but I don't regret picking this one up at all. And I'm actually gonna try Lament of Zors out.

For context I played exclusively with a keyboard: Space to jump, ESDF for movement, W for right dash, R for left dash, J to attack, K for spells and I for class abilities. imo this is the best setup for non-controller players.

[h1]Rogue Legacy is Really Hard[/h1]

My first life, I played as Sir Lee in the year 730 AD, and got through about 2 rooms before dying to a spinning picture frame. But ashes to ashes, dust to dust, and another life for the castle, and another, and another...

Each time I learned a little more about how to deal with enemies:
[list]
[*]Spinning Picture Frame? Hit it twice before it gets a chance to spin away.
[*]Flaming Skull? Attack, dash opposite and attack again.
[*]Flame projectile mage? Find a ledge to stand under, and wait for him to exhaust his attack.
[*]Ice mage? Wait for him to cast his icicle spell, then jump-attack him twice
[/list]
Coming back to rooms that previously gave you a lot of trouble, and kicking their butts is the core gameplay loop, and is by far the most fulfilling part of the game. More on this later.

[h1]The -like in Roguelike[/h1]

When you die, you carry on your castle-raiding legacy by selecting one of three heirs. Each heir has a “class” and “traits”.

Classes massively affect how a run is played. Barbarians are tanky, Knaves are glass cannons. Mages can cast extra spells. You only get to choose from 3 heirs when you die, so you can’t always pick the class you want. I like this mechanic, since it forces you to experiment. Lichking became one of my favorite classes to clear the castle with because of his huge crowstorm spell. Spellblade became one of my favorite classes to fight bosses with, because of his reliable range.

Also consider Traits when picking an heir. You can have dwarves, giants, skinnies, fatties. There are other traits too, like ADHD which gives 30% extra movement speed. Also neutral traits that have novelty the first few times you see them. It’s fun to see an heir with Coprolalia swear every time they get hit, or have jumbled letters due to dyslexia.

My biggest criticism of the game are negative traits, because they get in the way of having fun. Getting Dextrocardia, which switches your HP and Mana pools is not fun; I have yet to encounter a time when it doesn’t just remove possible heirs. Vertigo is something that I picked once or twice, but quickly realized it’s just a speedrun to the next generation. Nearsightedness and farsightedness don’t affect gameplay; they’re just annoying.

You can also upgrade your family castle in between lives, which gives your heirs abilities and stat bonuses. A “problem” is that the “good” upgrades to get aren’t the “fun” ones. Increasing your attack damage, or later your crit chance/damage is outright better than everything else, and most equipment upgrades similarly just boost stats. That’s not to say that there aren’t advantages to this design though. There was not that much difference between my first character, Sir Lee in 730 AD, and my last character Leona VIII in 13,122 AD, and in theory I could’ve beaten the game with Sir Lee, in fact, several people have!

[h1]Lose is Improve[/h1]

The best part of Rogue Legacy though, is that it’s fun and fulfilling to improve at the game. When I entered a new region of the castle, I died. a lot. But with each death I slowly learned enemy attack patterns. Eventually, I was able to reliably fully clear the first section, Castle Hamson, and was ready to take on Khidr, the first boss of the game. I don’t know how many lives Khidr took, but in terms of time the first boss in the game took me over an hour, with each life lasting 2-3 minutes.

Moving on to the Forest, then the Maya then the Darkness and the final boss repeating the same steps, I ended up at Leona VIII in 13,122 AD,  516 generations removed from Sir Lee! But this was just the first step.

Enter New Game+ Every enemy that I just fought in the regular castle? Now they have enhanced abilities. Remember the Ice Wizard who would shoot in 8 directions? Now it’s 16! Enter New Game++ enemies that previously shot in 8 directions now shoot a torrent icicles at you, larger and more numerous than before! Despite the task of killing 4 bosses and the final boss being unchanged from the regular game, it still took 200 and 100 lives respectively to beat NG+(+).

Then there are the Neo-Bosses, which are enhanced versions of the regular bosses. I think around a third of my hours on the game alone were from learning the attack patterns and repeatedly dying to Neo-Khidr, Alexander IV, Ponce de Freon, Astrodotus and Brohannes, but it’s all worth it, since it’s training for the final challenge of the game.

Even though Neo-Bosses are really hard, they aren't the greatest challenge, Thanatophobia (beat the game in 15 or fewer lives) is. The catch? You do it in the standard game, not NG+. This is where all the practice and dying came in handy, because going back to 8 directions instead of a torrent is trivial by comparison. It still took me a few tries, but with all the practice my final Thanatophobia run took just 7 lives, way down from my original 516.

Becoming an unstoppable, highly stated character is not what makes Rogue Legacy fun, but rather mastering the game, and Rogue Legacy gives all the tools and challenges to master the game.

I recommend Rogue Legacy to all those looking for a challenge and give it my Bad !@# seal of approval!

P.S:
Music: Average
Theme: Charming
Graphics: Sharp and Clear

If you're a casual gamer, Rogue Legacy probably isn't for you.
If you aren't a twitch-master with a black-belt in XBox Controller (or if you lack an XBox Controller), Rogue Legacy probably isn't for you.
If you liked actual Rogue, Rogue Legacy almost certainly isn't for you.
If you don't enjoy grinding, Rogue Legacy probably isn't for you.

All those hyperventilating reviews for Rogue... probably from hard-core gamers.  The types who spend thousands on gaming yearly.  Who are [i]proud[/i] of the pain they put in, and dismissive of anyone insufficiently dedicated to do the same.

[i]This[/i] game is about futilely trying to survive long enough to collect a little bit of treasure, necessary to upgrade your next life with better skills, equipment, etc., against a variety of clever but overwhelming enemies in real-time.  The idea is that death is a feature, but... only if you survive long enough to collect enough treasure for another upgrade.  More about that in a moment.

In contrast, actual [i]Rogue[/i], and immediate followers such as Angband and Nethack, plus spiritual descendants such as Telengard, Temple of Apshai and the early Ultimas, were [i]turn-based[/i] dungeon exploration games.  You move, cast a spell, whatever, and then the enemies do something and you, in your own time, respond.  Death was (often) death, called "perma-death" if you weren't allowed to save your game, and it [i]could[/i] be frequent... but it wasn't frenetic.

Legacy, in contrast, is a high-speed action game.  The idea is, you die a lot, but eventually you upgrade to the point where you can survive.

That's bunk.  You don't.  You die a lot, you upgrade a bit, but upgrades become exponentially more expensive.  Fast.  It's not like Diablo or Fate, where you can re-enter a higher (deeper) level of the dungeon.  

Rogue Legacy is a game for twitch-game fanatics who see constant death and failure to advance as features.  For everyone else, an early Duke Nuke'm is probably a better match.

The idea is fun but I can't recommend the game (at all) for two main reasons:

(1) the controls/ hitboxes are nowhere near as precise as they need to be. The combat ends up being a lot of enemies whose attacks are near impossible to dodge (not to mention one boss whose attacks come from off-screen). A lot of roguelikes create progression by making the game very hard and letting the player naturally get better. In Rogue Legacy, you get better by buying upgrades to your character which isn't bad in and of itself but I think it masks the fact that there is no real possibility to get better by becoming more skilful. Enemies become easier because you can tank them, not because you're better at the game.

And (2), the roguelike elements are really surface level. The different classes are very similar and for a lot of them the only perceivable differences aren't in gameplay but just the size of health bars. The other changing element of the game, the legacy, isn't any better. So few of the conditions actually change gameplay. A surprising amount are purely visual changes and a lot of those that aren't don't feel very different (less knockback etc). There are very few that change the way that any character might play. And just to nitpick, I know some of the medical conditions aren't defined correctly.

In short, there are far far better games if you want to play a side-scrolling platformer or a roguelike.

85783640.review:
Rogue Legacy was the first roguelite I've played, back in 2013. It also made me fall in love with the genre, due to it being such an addictive and exhilarating experience. It was the first time I experience the thrill of having a new, unique run, with special traits and different level compositions.

It was great. I replayed it a couple years ago, and it still is great. Sure, it doesn't have the same depth of newer roguelites/likes, like Dead Cells or Enter the Gungeon, but it still is an amazing experience in 2020.

Let's talk about what the game:

Let's start with the [b]sound[/b]:
the SFX is great. There's an oomph feeling when you hit enemies, when they hit you, when the spikes hurt you, or when you jump. They're great because there's not a single sound out of place. Everything fits, everything is the way you would've imagined it before you listened the sound.
The music is one of the best things in the game. It's beautifully composed, and it makes so much sense when you play it; depending on your location, a different soundtrack will play, and they fit the theme so well. In the dungeons, you'll hear a metallic, slavery, deep music that immerses you in place.

Following up, [b]graphics[/b]:
They're not incredible in the sense that you'll be amazed by them, but that's not the point of them. The artistic direction revolves around a feeling. A mixture of retro and modern, with semi-pixelated visual effects, but still of high quality. A direction with a lot of personality. So good and so cute. Though it might not be everyone's cup of tea.
The visual effects follow that design and fit everything, there's nothing out of place.

Next, [b]story[/b]:
Nothing really remarkable, it's interesting, funny, and a bit, if not a lot, dark. It's a great addition to the game, and it makes you want to dig in the lore when you find journals with piece of lore.

The most important, and last feature, the [b]gameplay[/b]:
This is the meat of the game. The most enjoyable and thrilling part. It isn't of gigantic depth, full of combos, and abilities. There are a few abilities, basically no combos, and there's not a lot of depth in it, but it doesn't matter. There's a learning curve, and once you master it, something beautiful happens. You need reflexes. You need to perceive and understand your surroundings, learn to read the enemies, and counter their abilities. It's so much fun.

There's one main feature, a feature that is the heart of Rogue Legacy: The heirs. Everytime you die, a new heir will take your place. You'll be able to pick between a few of them, each of them with their own traits, which aren't always good. Normally, these traits are genetical, which means, your heir might suffer from gigantism, flatulence, color blindness, and so on. Some of these traits will adjust better to your style, while others will help you get lore, complete puzzles, or obtain chests. Some others are just useless, and fun, but hey, they add to the game.

Talking about when you die: you also have the possibility to spend the coins earned in your run to upgrade your castle, which means upgrading your character, your chances, your possibilities, and your rewards in different ways. If you don't spend these coins, they'll be lost [b]forever[/b], which makes for an interesting element: the better you are at the game, the faster you will proceed. The worse you're at it, the slower. But that's not bad, that's good, because while a fast player might need fewer upgrades to reach the same point, the slower one will also have the chance to reach that place once he's better prepared and more experienced.

Bosses are hard, enemies can be hard, but there's not a lot of unfairness in the game. Not many cheap attacks, just a few, and you learn to counter them, or act around them. It's really fun and my favorite part of the game.

So, I recommend this to people that aren't experienced in rogue-lites, and want to dip their toes in it, and in general to every played that likes the genre. It's one of my favorites because in the simplicity is where the fun and beauty resides. 

Plus, it's ultra cheap right now.

In the context of when it was released, Rogue Legacy was fantastic, and it still holds up today. The systems of platforming, combat, and progression are all satisfying without being overbearing. In terms of overall structure, the game is a bit more forgiving than other roguelike/lites in that much of the rewards collected in each run are retained afterwards. This means that the game can be a bit of a grind at points for many players, but it still provides plenty of challenge; not every player has the time or motivation to finish running through multiple worlds and bosses in a single life. 

If you're new to the genre, this is a great starting point with a lot of well-designed content and charm. If you're an experienced roguelite player and somehow haven't played this, it's well-worth taking a look at a significantly genre entry that was released close to the beginning of the last decade.

I love this game. It is everything I would want a roguelite to be. There are three major areas where this game stands out in the genre for me:

1. The permanent upgrades. There is a huge multi-branching skill tree. Then you have equipment you can upgrade. Then you have new Runes that you can find and equip. There is so much to upgrade and customize that it makes every bit of gold you find and every death feel worthwhile.

77731301.review:
Rogue Legacy is a small game which at first glance seems like a standard upgrading rogue-like. And it is definitely that but by introducing a story and the idea of heirs, the gameplay is allowed to blossom. After you have an unsuccessful run and your current character is killed, their heir takes up the mantle. You choose from one of three heirs, each with multiple possible combinations of standard classes and the more interesting "traits". Classes range from Paladin to Rogue to Mage to more powerful classes later on after upgrading. Traits are where, in my opinion, the game makes the way you play change drastically. For example, you may be a far-sighted dwarf. This means you have a blurred radius around your character who is also half the normal size. Being shorter makes it easier to dodge but your sword is shorter so to melee attack you need to get even closer to the enemy at further risk to your health bar. This is only one combination of the multitude possible. 

The castle is procedurally generated each time so there's no memorization involved unless you choose to 'lock' down the castle, preventing it from changing at a cost of lower rewards.
Without spoiling too much of the game itself, there are multiple bosses in different regions you need to fight in order to progress and different loadouts suit different bosses so one character may be superbly equipped to deal with one but ill-equipped to deal with another. So don't worry if you can't beat all the bosses in one life as it carries over until you beat the final boss.

If you are looking for a postgame, there is a NG+ which scales up the monsters to higher levels to challenge you. There are also additional secret bosses who I won't talk about but they are optional and if you fail you don't die so retry as many times as you would like.

Overall, the gameplay can get repetitive which is often a pitfull of roguelikes but it makes up for it with interesting mechanics, procedural generation and a phenomenal artstyle. Would wholly recommend to anyone who enjoys roguelikes or even skill based platforming fighting. 

9/10

Rogue Legacy is a cute rogue-like platformer with a unique legacy mechanic, but its paper-thin story and masochistic grind only rewards those that are willing to drag themselves through content that grows old after the first couple hours.

Every one of your descendents has some kind of genetic quirk or another. Some will hinder, some will aid you, and others are just silly. These are then combined with the game's many classes. Once in a blue moon you'll be graced with a really good gene/class combination, other times you'll be dealt a generation of descendents who are just better off dead.

The levels are procedurally generated, but there are only four different terrains in the castle. Many of the enemies are just palette swaps of lower level enemies with increased powers, so much of the game starts to feel stale after a while. If I weren't playing this during lockdown, I would quit much earlier.

As you progress through the game, you earn gold which can be spent on upgrades for future members of your family... but any excess gold is immediately taken by the castle's gatekeeper, the Reaper. This is the most frustrating aspect of the game, as you end up only upgrading incrementally after you die. If you're unlucky, you'll die before you earn enough gold to purchase a single upgrade, making the entire run a complete waste of time. 

This game can't be considered a proper Metroidvania, however. While gameplay hinges on exploration of its procedurally generated dungeon, you don't receive any unlocks that change how you explore the game in any meaningful way like a traditional Metroidvania. 

I do not recommend this game at its current price point of $15. If you are a rogue-like and platformer/metroidvania fan, it may be worth picking up in a bundle or when deeply discounted, but the grind will repel most players.

I first played Rogue Legacy as a PS4 demo at Target in 2013, and ever since I've been enchanted by the idea of rogue-likes. When I finally bought the game in 2015, I played on-and-off for about 20 hours or so and then gave up, having believed Khidr was something I'd need to grind for. When I came back last month, I went straight to Khidr and absolutely stomped the poor fool. And then I proceeded to stomp the Forest. The game lets you get away with grinding to a stupid level, and after 3 hours you'll have seen all of the procedurally generated rooms. 
This was only compounded by the fact that this game has a total of 3 classes worth a damn: the Shinobi/Hokage, the Miner/Spelunker, and the Mage/Archmage. Close quarters combat is a sometimes-food. You'll have enough Mana and enough potions laying around to replenish your spam, which expedites this already relatively easy game, and the ability to choose between 2 sets of 3 spells where one is ridiculously good and the other sucks lobotomizes the game. I beat every boss by pulling out the spikes or the flamewheel as an Archmage.
The Spelunker is a weak class, but it sure doesn't need to stick around long. You can bum around the Castle and receive more than enough loot. I was never incentivized to push into the Maya or the otherwise more weighty regions because the opportunity for loot in them was too low just by design. Oh, but magic will save you if your sword damage is still lacking.
The Hokage is admittedly a class that you'll never use once you've upgraded your Mana enough, but it's yet another class to rush through the early game. I will also say that this class is infinitely superior to the Assassin, because crits should never be a core design concept.
Every other class is rendered worthless in comparison due to their lack of mobility or the amount of time it takes to whack at an enemy.

I really love this game, and I still do, but it just didn't balance itself too well. It helped the genre a ton, and I can appreciate that, but the core gameplay loop gets boring after beating the way-too-easy final boss. Rogue Legacy 2 seems to still be barren as well, unfortunately.

75638044.review:
Rogue Legacy is a great platformer, especially if you like RPG-style character progression.

The core gameplay is simple fun and polished, and the surrounding systems add a lot of depth and unique mechanics.

The descendant system is my favorite part! After every death you choose your heir from a group of three candidates. Their classes, spells, and birth traits are all random, and this opens so much replayability and playstyles for the game.

The other systems are somewhat a mixed bag.

You can unlock perks and items with gold, and find other permanent upgrades within the dungeon. Some players will love this and build their ideal character, but it also impacts the difficulty balance for the rest of the game. New enemies and bosses need much higher stats to stay competitive, and this turns them into damage sponges. No matter your skill there will be moments where you just need to grind for higher stats.

The dungeon is procedurally generated every time you do a run. It takes dozens of premade rooms and arranges them into unique layouts.
I don't think this reaches its full potential for variety, especially when most rooms in new zones are just reskins of earlier rooms. However the generated dungeons do a great job of keeping you in the moment and finding your way, instead of just memorizing the layout. These dungeons also manage a very consistent difficulty between runs, and that impresses me a lot.

Overall Rogue Legacy is great! It’s not one of my favorite platformers but it does so much right and I can definitely see the appeal.

Game is punishingly balanced against the player in the early game, but once you break through a certain threshold of gold income per run, the difficulty falls apart and it becomes extremely easy.

My first attempts at the game were frustratingly short, and the very limited amount of gold you earn prevents you from many of the meaningful upgrades in the Manor skill tree. I gave up on it for a long time, then tried revisiting it years later. Once I was able to last longer as a barbarian and struggle through finding some lucky chests at the boss doors a few times, and with luck from finding the Obdol item that lets you keep gold for two runs temporarily, I was able to buy income upgrades and the spelunker class, which greatly sped up the skill tree unlocks. From there, dumping all your points into health and a few weapon/vampirism/damage upgrades makes the game snowball out of control and you get to see the castle for what it really is.

Generally each "wing" is 24-26 rooms, and you're looking for chests or the boss rooms, since they always have a health drop and two chests even whether you've beaten the boss or not. Bosses are kind of fun, but just the largest versions of the slime, eye, skull and wisp enemies you'll find many of, and they are only repeatable on New Game+ runs. The final boss is pretty underwhelming and mostly a stat check. graphics and environments are okay with some charm, but there's many annoying room designs that punish you for not being a dwarf character, or having the correct spell to hit enemies behind walls or floors. There's many runes and blueprints to chase down but most of them are pretty boring and it only makes sense to use a few dedicated items to toughen yourself up.

It's sometimes satisfying to stumble into a room full of many mages or eyeballs and successfully bob and weave around all the projectiles and carefully clear the room out, but it takes a long time to get to the point where you can do any meaningful damage or survive many encounters, which is where the game's tuning falls very short. It's just too hard in the first 15 minutes, and way too easy once you've reached the tipping point, and a lot of the game ends up being very shallow, especially for built-up profiles. (I did beat the game finally, out of spite rather than fun)

A completely modernized "Ghosts and Goblins" 2D side scrolling action/platformer that borrows heavily from other classics in the so called Metroidvania genre.

Where it deviates the most is the addition of the Rogue-Lite random-dungeon, and the one-life per adventure mechanic that has you continue the adventure with your heir each time you die. The new legacy of your heir carries on with your inherited equipment and castle upgrades (permanent bonuses and skill options) while also bringing variety with new traits and skills each time.

If metroidvania is a genre you enjoy this has endless replay value as you delve deeper into the castle each time in an effort to make your legacy even stronger so that your next heir can go even further. Whether you just play this casually and die frequently goofing around or attack it hardcore and really invest the time to master the boss fights, there's a never ending supply of things to kill and smash.

Note: While the keyboard controls (no mouse) are adequate, this is even better with a joystick or gamepad.

Ever want to know what it's like to be a hero with hypergonadism?  How about baldness? Shortsighted? Maybe I.B.S?  Well then this is your game!  And more...but just so awesome!

This defined Rogue-Like -  where you have one life, then start again but carry along your predecessors things - in this it's money, your castle and belongings (like armour n swords) and magic abilities that carry on.  

But each time it's the next in line so to say, the next on the chopping block?  It creates a GIANT family tree as you play of each relative who tried and subsequently failed to complete the game. 

Depends on how well you play, but a lot to do with what random fate has dealt you in terms of 'traits' like mentioned above.  Some are hilarious traits, the I.B.S. is a true fav given random fart noises are the only addition.  Some are very detrimental - the eyesight related ones for sure fit into that category and make things blurry or dark - but some are good too and give access to special areas (like dwarfisim which makes ya small) or can show where enemies are.

You get money, upgrade your castle, buy things and slowly progress through various areas which are procedurally generated meaning sometimes it's easy - sometimes the first room is impossible.

Enemies only vary so much but their difficulty changes quite a bit in each area.  Plus depending on the mix of spikes and enemies can make quite varying unique challenges regardless.  Plus bosses who will destroy you.  Over and over.  But that's all good cause it just makes you want to get back in there and try again (trust me!).

Either way, it is all fun and great for some local players to share between plays and see who gets further or kills more enemies or just have a laugh!

This isn't really a rogue-like/rogue-lite. It's just a basic action platformer, and a grindy one at that.

The reason this game isn't really a rogue-like/rogue-lite is because you can't find anything within a run to change things. There are no items you can pick up to change how you attack, passive items to give you stat buffs, etc… Your character at the start of the run will be exactly the same by the end of the run. The only thing that you can pick up is gold, and you can't even spend that gold within a run. You can only spend this gold once the run ends. Therefore, there's not much replayability as far as I am concerned.

That would be completely fine if the core gameplay was fun. Unfortunately, it's not THAT great. The characters you play as are very basic. They can attack, dash, do multiple jumps, magic attack, and a special ability. The magic attack is pretty much irrelevant because it costs mana and you can't regenerate mana unless you pick up MP potions, which drop very rarely. The special abilities are also almost all defensive abilities, so it's not like they're super fun to use. They also cost mana, so you're going to want to save them for bosses. So that leaves you with attacking, dashing, and jumping……..That's really basic -_-. To be fair, developers can make playing as basic characters incredibly fun to play. I mean hell, it can be argued that player characters in Dark Souls and Hollow Knight are basic, and those are some of my favorite games.

This game certainly has the POTENTIAL to be as great as those games. The controls are very precise and combat is fast paced. If you make 1 mistake like attacking when you should've jumped, you're going to get hit. Fine-tuning a game to this degree isn't easy, and this forces every enemy to pose a decent challenge. In every room, you have to quickly take in your surroundings and figure out how best to deal with all the enemies while minimizing the damage you take. I mean sometimes you have to use tactics such as only approaching an enemy from below instead of directly from the left/right of them. This is all great.

What's not so great, and what's limiting this game's potential, is the over-emphasis on offense. Basically, if it takes you more than 3 hits to kill an enemy, you're not going to progress. This is because, like I said, the game is fast-paced. If you take too long to kill 1 enemy, another enemy will start attacking you. The problem is that you can't just dodge every single attack. To be specific, you can dodge AN enemy, but you can't dodge MULTIPLE enemies. Eventually you'll get swarmed and get caught in undodgeable scenarios. It doesn't help that the game is pretty zoomed in and you don't get invincibility frames on your dash. So killing enemies quickly is an absolute must.

This is where the grindy part comes in. Like I said before, you can't find anything within a run to change things. You have to pick up gold and spend it once you die. So this game is really just a matter of grinding enough gold in order to beat it. I.e., once you've grinded enough gold to kill the enemies you want within 1 hit, you're probably going to beat that level. 2 bosses are a perfect example of this: Alexander and Herodotus. These bosses summon minions throughout the battle with no cap on the number of minions that can be summoned. If you can't kill these minions fast enough (i.e. in 1 hit), there's no way in hell you're going to beat the boss. So these bosses, and arguably all of the bosses, serve as effective walls for the grinding.

Ultimately, I don't see myself replaying this game. While I've beaten the game and unlocked new game plus, this game is not really a rogue-lite since I know beating new game plus is going to be about grinding enough levels to quickly kill enemies. That means I have to rate it based on the time I played, and that time wasn't all that fun because the game is fairly basic with the difficulty really only coming from the grinding. So yea, I wouldn't really recommend this game.

Y este "Rogue Legacy" que nos ocupa es una maravilla. Tras verlo en casa de ese amigo, me lo pillé en ps3 y le dí muchísimo. Y ahora le he vuelto a dar más. Pero... de que va esto?

Pues somos un caballero que tiene que cumplir una misión en un castillo maldito. Casi con total seguridad moriremos, y cuando lo hagamos, uno de nuestros descendientes (a elegir entre 3) deberá tomar el testigo y completar dicha misión.

Pero el castillo está maldito, y cada vez que uno de nuestros descendientes entra, es diferente. Existe un método para "bloquear" el castillo y que sea igual que el anterior, pero al coste de un 40% del oro que encontremos.

Hablemos de los descendientes, que a fin de cuentas, són los que tendrán que lidiar con el problema en cuestión. Todos nuestros descendientes tendrán algún atributo, que en algunos casos puede ser positivo, en otros negativo, y en otros irrelevante. 
Algunos ejemplos de atributos positivos serian: No tienes pulso en los pies (no te afectan las trampas de pinchos), conduces la electricidad (las plataformas siempre están abiertas), trastornos compulsivos (obtienes pm's por romper objetos), etc.
Algunos ejemplos negativos serian: Dislexia (los textos salen desordenados), daltonismo (se ve todo en blanco y negro), miopia...
Algunos ejemplos irrelevantes serian: Calvicie, Gay, Exageración... ninguno de estos tiene efecto alguno en el personaje, por eso digo que són irrelevantes. En el caso de la exageración, simplemente cada golpe nos marcará un daño de 2500 de daño, pero la cifra real de daño será la normal (25, por ejemplo).

Con cada heredero que juguemos, irá recogiendo oro que al morir, nos permitirá comprar mejoras de vida, ataque, magia, crítico, mejoras de clases, nuevas clases, y un largo etc. Cada vez que compremos una mejora, el coste de las demás se incrementará ligeramente.

Tambien encontraremos planos de armadura y runas, que podremos equipar antes de entrar al castillo (y comprarlas, claro).

Respecto a lo demás... técnicamente más que correcto, la música está bien, y lo único que me chirría, es que en las retransmisiones, el juego da un bajón de fps bien gordo. Desconozco el motivo. El control es muy bueno y la dificultad diria que alta/muy alta. Morireis muchísimo (o yo lo hice al menos) y en consecuencia os picaréis un montón.

Personalmente, creo que la manera de integrar los elementos rogue es magistral. Que sea tu familia la que generación tras generación luche para quitar la maldición del castillo, tiene todo el sentido del mundo. De hecho, la excusa de los Belmont en Castlevania y el castillo de Drácula (que está maldito y tiene muchas formas), aquí me da la impresión de estar muchísimo mejor llevado a cabo e implementado.

Y no se me ocurre mucho más asi a bote pronto. Lo cierto es que es el mejor rogue (para mi), y si os gusta el género me sorprenderia que no los hubieseis probado ya. De modo que le voy a cascar un 9 sin siquiera parpadear, y SI, recomendadísimo.

The idea behind Rogue Legacy is pretty clever and its execution is also quite solid.  With all the different knights that can be generated, you'll need to switch up how you play on a regular basis.  Learning enemy attack and movement patterns is as important as improving your character.  If you play the game a second time, you'll find yourself making a lot more progress even with the first couple of characters that are generated.

The controls of this game feel nice, and you have several different movement options (like an air dash and a double jump) that allow you to approach fights and platforming however you want.

If you choose the right approach to fighting the enemies in a room, you can generally escape unharmed, though sometimes a room is generated that would be nearly impossible to get through without damage.  At that point, you have to make a judgement call about whether that room is worth your time or not.

The upgrade tree provides a lot of options, and the vast majority of these are useful.  The game encourages you to even out your stats by making a particular stat cost more every time you upgrade it.  This means that you'll be able to swap between a mage and a knight quite easily, but you probably won't make a lot of meaningful long-term build choices.  Often I just found myself upgrading whatever was most relevant to the character I was using.  The biggest problem is that all of the stats cap eventually, which means that if you play NG+, you eventually won't have any use for your money whatsoever.  I think there should have been some use for your cash in NG+ that would never become obsolete.

Another issue is the way that runes were handled.  Because each set of runes is the same, you'll be acquiring duplicates of the same runes that you already have for probably half the game.  This means that the faerie chests aren't very exciting to open until you've collected all of the runes.

But beyond those issues, the core gameplay is solid, and I definitely recommend this game.
