TL:DR: Rogue Legacy is a game almost entirely focused on time spent, rather than skill.

Pros:
Decent controls; pogo-ing off of enemies feels good.
Good graphics; it knows what it's going for, and it does it... okay.

Cons:
Not much skill involved; going to a new area without massive grinding will result in you dying in one or two hits from anything, and if you haven't randomly found the super-rare and super-expensive runes that allow you to airdash, double jump, etc, you're most likely not going to have the tools necessary to dodge any of the new attacks either. Not to mention that those new enemies will take about a dozen hits to defeat each, giving them ample time to return fire...

Although moving around isn't difficult, it's quite slow. Thankfully not as bad as Towerclimb, but slow enough that the first zone is going to get old fast.

The entire family tree gimmick. Most of the time, you'll have some inconvenient-but-ultimately-harmless things to deal with. Maybe you randomly fart, which creates a small visual effect and a noise. Maybe the screen has a old-timey black-and-white-like effect. Other times, your screen will be flipped both vertically and horizontally, you can't see your HUD, and your hitbox is about twice as large as normal. This is problematic, considering if you don't have a choice in the matter, your only option is to intentionally get yourself killed to reroll your awful run. Thus wasting multiple minutes.

The combat. You have precisely three attacks. A swing that covers your front, as well as behind you, a downward stab that will bounce you upward if it hits, and your magic attack (which has limited uses). 90% of the time, you'll only be using the first for combat, the second for puzzles, and the third for bosses. This is unaffected by anything else; your only melee options are swords, which are all palette-swaps with stat changes (not interesting stat changes, mind you; this one has 10% more damage. Ooh, fancy.). The class system is pretty much irrelevant; none of them give any meaningful bonuses, so you can just ignore them entirely without missing anything. You jump or walk toward enemy, press attack button once or twice (if you're in a level-appropriate area, otherwise you'll die before coming close to an enemy, or getting started on their massive healthbar), and move on. Your movement options are similarly diverse; you can walk, and you can jump. Sometimes there are platforms that you activate using the downward stab, which is exclusively used for this since it sucks in every other regard. Even Mario Bros had more options; you could both sprint AND crouch, in addition to walking and jumping.

It boils down to just mindlessly grinding until you outclass everything in stats, and it's not exactly a good example of that, either. Reactor Incremental, for example, on Kongregate, for free, lets you attempt to customize your reactor in order to produce as much power as possible. If you're looking to spend time and $15, this is the game for you. If you're looking to have fun, look somewhere else.

62099413.review:
Let me preface my review by pointing out, I'm not a mere casual gamer. I love a challenge; I have a blast playing the Dark Souls series (which honestly doesn't even feel hard to me), old-school RPGs, and Monster Hunter. I was also a big fan of "Roguelites", which followed the general formula of Roguelike games but also allowed for metaprogression; in particular, I was a fan of Azure Dreams, and sunk hundreds of hours into it. I grew up loving to find challenges and figure out how to overcome them using strategy and thinking out an approach.

Now, let's talk about Rogue Legacy.

Rogue Legacy is an action platformer vaguely reminiscent of metroidvania games. You tackle the castle, you collect gold, you die, you spend the gold to upgrade your next character, rinse and repeat. You continue this cycle, while learning enemy patterns and acquiring treasures in the form of Runes and Equipment Blueprints. 

On paper, it's a fine and excellent standard roguelike formula. In practice, however, it plays absolutely nothing like roguelikes/lites you may have experienced in the past.

Most roguelikes/lites require you to plan out your approach, carefully considering your movements and taking calculated risks while using every possible item, spell, weapon, tactic, or advantage of literally any kind to survive. 

Rogue Legacy is nothing like this. There are some areas where you need to think out your approach, but in general the most complex thinking comes in the form of "Hmm, what do I need in order to acquire that Fairy Chest?", and remembering to lock the castle with the Architect if you get what you need.

The other 95% of the game is twitch reflexes, praying to god that you don't get swarmed by enemies that can shoot through walls, trying desperately to avoid cheap contact damage, and just generally dealing with complete bullet hell situations minus the bullets and with extra doses of hell. While being deprived of anything resembling healing or mana restoration 99% of the time unless you specifically choose to play a class that gives you MP regeneration as a feature.

It technically follows the surface-level formula of a roguelike. "Procedurally randomize everything, place the player against impossible odds, and make them want to tear their hair out in frustration." However, because it replaces the strategic thinking of most roguelikes with twitch reflexes and bullet hell dodging, it's just not the same experience.

Rogue Legacy is for players that enjoy extremely fast-paced, incredibly unforgiving and often downright unfair gameplay. No matter how many times you attempt to play, the game WILL figure out new ways to screw you over... or otherwise just subject you to the same screw-you's that worked before.

Got a character with Gigantism? Prepare for spike-filled precision-platforming to take up every room. Pick a miner to try and get some gold? Every other room will have an enemy that's far above the level of what you should be fighting. Pick a combat-focused class? Enjoy being swarmed by projectiles and contact-damage-abusing enemies at every possible turn.

I thought we moved past contact damage as a mechanic. You could call it a throwback to oldschool gaming. I call it cheap and lazy fake difficulty; the reason contact damage was normalized by early games is because in the early stages of gaming, it was much more difficult to program relatively intelligent AI to provide a challenge without the use of contact damage. Considering how much the gaming industry has developed, there is no longer any excuse to rely on contact damage combined with Depth Perplexion for 90% of the challenge in the game.

I want to like Rogue Legacy, and I keep coming back to it thinking "Maybe it's not as unfair as I remember", only to quickly be reminded that, yes, it's incredibly brutal and unfair in just about every possible way except for the hitboxes themselves. There's "Difficult", and then there's "Why would you throw your skull against this brick wall more than once or twice?"

For those who want the bragging rights and have nothing better to do all day but repeatedly throw themselves at this hellishly, unfairly difficult game, I salute you and respect your decision. For those of us who are actually sane (or at least don't have godlike reflexes and inherent slow-motion perception of the world around us), pass this one up and play dark souls instead. It's still a challenging game, but at least it's actually fair and doesnt depend on cheap gotchas, contact damage, and ledge bats to kill you. (Well, aside from the capra demon.)

Original review Posted January 19, 2020.

I once again attempted to play this game on December 9, 2021 upon watching a Rogue Legacy 2 Let's Play video thinking maybe I could attempt to beat it to have it under my belt before eventually playing Rogue Legacy 2. Yeah no. It's just as ridiculously unfair and obnoxious in its many enemy-favoring and player-crippling mechanics as I remember. Still not recommended.

It was fun for the first few hours, then the regular gameplay after that just got kind of... dull. The bosses and enemies really aren't that interesting, and even though the game's NG+ does bother to change up the enemies instead of just increasing their HP and damage, it's not super good. It was painful and boring to 100% this game, even though I've spent much more time 100%ing other games.

I think that the only fun part of this game after the initial high when I bought it was the Thanatophobia achievement since you can't just brute force your way through the game and have to actually do some roguish stuff to maximize your gold with every run so that you can beat the game in under 15 deaths. It adds a sense of thrill to the game, but you unfortunately need to beat the game once or twice to get the skills to do it.

I wouldn't buy it even for a massive discount. It's the most generic roguelite around. Still, if you do buy it, don't try to 100% it: beat the game, ignore NG+, and then go for Thanatophobia. That's probably the most fun way to play it, I think.

On the contrary, Monolith and Spelunky are both far better roguelike games that are usually about the same price as Rogue Legacy. Monolith has super fun shooty bullet combat and fun boss battles, and Spelunky is just brutal cave exploring action. Buy those two instead.

This game sounds perfect for me in paper: 2d metroidvania with some rpg-mechanics and grinding. For the first 10 minutes I was enjoying it quite a bit but after that I started to realize that RNG in this game should've been balanced better. Even hilarious character descriptions and traits aren't saving this game for me.

In games where maps are generated randomly, algorithms usually make sure that you don't get stuck and you can still progress. In this game you can get stuck if you don't have correct abilities or if enemies are 10x stronger than you. Some quests will be impossible to complete because how random enemy and corridor spawns can be. You can also get stuck because RNG doesn't give you enough gold for multiple dungeon runs or decides to kill you instantly with a pitfall. If you want to keep some map for some reason that will cost you and every time you enter the castle, it will cost all of your gold...

I don't mind RNG in the games but I do want feel like I'm having some progress, even if it was slow. Here it stops after a while and your progress will be under mercy of RNG gods.

More frustrating than fun, and I say that as someone who loves rogue -likes and -lites. 

Plenty of great roguelikes will screw you over with RNG, but that's part of the expectation. It's on you to be resourceful so you can handle crisis as they emerge. You have to be calculated in your risks and give yourself the best odds of survival. It's all part of the fun and the challenge.

This game, however, saps the fun away and turns it into pure frustration. Technically this game has far less RNG than a traditional roguelike, but in effect it has way more. Treasure chests placed on spike, leaps of faith where you can fall into enemies and take damage, enemies hitting you and bumping you into more enemies making one attack take the majority of you hit points, and all manner of fake difficulty plague this game. At least in a typical roguelike you know it's at the mercy of the computer whether you crit or not for instance. Here it feels like the game is blaming you for not magically predicting the Cat Mario-like nigh unavoidable death traps it throws at you. Screw this.

[H1]Introduction[/h1]

The plot is very classic, you are a knight and you need to control a castle.
Four seals, each are guarded by a boss, leading to the final boss.
Map are randomly generated.

[H1]Gameplay[/h1]

2D platformer, Rogue-like, you can't hack and slash through enemies mindlessly.
Navigate throught the randomly generated castle, Each room containing with a mix of monsters and/or traps.
You will sometime encounter green chest : these chest will be either appeared by killing some mini bosses, dangerous rooms or completing a challenge room (taking no damage or no jump for example)
Inside the green chest will be recipe to craft a sword, helm, chest or gauntlet ; or a "rune", giving you extra abilities ( flying during a short time, extra jump, ...)

When you will die ( it will happen a lot at first ), you will be able to choose one out of three of your child to take your place, each one with their random qualities and drawbacks.[spoiler] Extra mention for the "muscle spam" [/spoiler][spoiler] Your controller will vibrate for no reason, which is a funny addition [/spoiler] 
Afterward, you will be able to spend your gold on your "keep" to increase your characters stats, unlocking potential class ( for you next child ) and buying these runes and equipements with the recipe you got.
Another run will reset your gold, so spend you gold wisely.

[H1]100% achievement[/h1]

Once you know how to deal with enemies, getting all the achievements will be possible.
The achievement "Thanatophobia" (die less than 15 withouth the architect) is doable once you master the game [spoiler] I completed it with 10 childrens, so there is still room for mistakes[/spoiler]
Clear at least new game + to get 100%.

[H1]Conclusion[/h1]

A Challenging rogue-like 2D platformer, one game that you need to clear with knowledge, composure and maybe luck.
This game is worth a try, only if you are looking for a challenging game !

55688015.review:
This rogue-light platformer feels familiar right from the start, but a bit limiting. At first you can only jump and use your sword, having a particularly satisfying bounce slash that only works if timed juuuuuust right.

When beginning the tables are turned against you and it you really feel it. Death after death you will keep running into the castle, which is procedurally generated each run, meaning that each time you explore it, the layout will be different than before.

As the title of the game suggests you are in fact leaving a legacy, as each new life you start as a descendant of the character you’ve previously played. With each new life you can choose one of three descendants to play as, each with varying size, class, personal trait, and magic ability. For example you can get a colorblind mage and while you can defeat enemies by casting fireballs that circle around you, it’s pretty hard to navigate through the level safely. Some will have glaucoma, making the entire level blurry, others have Vertigo, forcing you to play through the level upside down with the UI mirrored. In the beginning these characters just feel like torture to play, but if you embrace the challenge it can be an intriguing test of your skills.

Speaking of torture, Rogue Legacy is HARD. Like an old school platformer, take a break and come back hard, especially in the beginning. 


The way that you progress in Rogue Legacy is using the coins that you collect each round to purchase upgrades to your estate which raises things like your attack stats, health, unlocks new characters and much more. You can also spend that money to unlock weapons, armor, and runes if you have found their blueprint in the game.

Even then Rogue Legacy will still give you a realty check if you aren’t giving it your all, but after you get deep into your unlocks you’ll be able to level the playing field a bit. For each piece of armor or weapon that you wield you can equip a rune. Runes can vary from giving you an extra jump, which can be stacked so that you can have a triple or quadruple jump, a dash ability or earning more coins throughout the level.

Overall, the game runs great on the the Switch, except for one crazy glitch that occured when I was in a middle of a great run, which really sucked, but the glitch was fun to experiment with.

It's sad, but I just can't recommend this game. It's too difficult, but for the wrong reasons. It's not just a matter of getting good, it's just plain bad game design.

This game is pretty much a "metroidvania meets bullet hell" rogue-like game, but at first you'd think it's just the metroidvania part. That's where things start getting wrong anyway, because the clunky controls make getting through the rooms without getting hit, either by running into enemies, projectiles or plain old spikes, a much more complicated feat that you'd like. Health and mana go down quickly and recovery is sparse (and percentage based, which hurts more than helps). Now, you'll likely still be able to manage through the the first area of the game and chance upon one of the other three, which is where the bullet hell parts come in. Every enemy you found gets on steroids and hits harder and much more often, making dodging nearly impossible, so you'll be dead pretty much as soon as you set foot on one of them.

So how do you prevent that? We're back to the metroidvania - time to level up. Which you do by accruing gold before you die and once you do spending it on upgrades to make your characters stronger. Only that upgrades don't really matter much without getting a lot of them, and they just happen to get costlier each time. So you're back to the castle and notice that you lose any money you didn't use and that you're hitting a wall because you need way more money than you can get before you're dead again. Now you're stuck, needing to try multiple times until you luck out, get enough money and thus a tiny bit stronger. Rinse and repeat and repeat and repeat and repeat. Repeat while enduring the small variety of palette swapped enemies and bosses.

I could get into more detail as how the game ruins your experience, but that pretty much sums up the worst points: it's unfair, and it becomes a way too boring grindfest. And even what could have been great ideas, like the whole class system along the different traits your character can get, gets screwed by the fact that you don't get to choose them (each time you pick one of three pre-generated characters) nor you can use a particular character for long enough since you'll die sooner than later. And even so, they end up feeling really similar since most of your damage is the sword-swing that every character shares.

For me, this game could have been one of my favorites, but it ended up falling short of expectations. It has a lot of elements that hit right up my alley, but somehow the combined product is an unplayable mess.

54893333.review:
Overall fun game but there's some jank that really messes me up.

1. [u] The Camera [/u]

It's zoomed in so far that I can't reliably drop through a platform without getting hit by an off-screen projectile. I know that zooming out would take away the challenge of one of the traits, but it would also take away a lot of frustration when getting hit by something off-screen.

2. [u] The Boss AI. [/u]

All of them have some form of RNG that can make them more or less difficult depending on how lucky you get. Based on my experience, both the regular and remix fights of the second and final boss are too erratic for me to reliably kill.

In the case of the final boss, he jumps, dashes, and uses his various attacks wildly making it extremely hard to predict what he's doing, and with certain attacks being spammable, you can often find yourself at the receiving end of a barrage of axes.

during his final phase he has two attacks that he can spam. One summons swords from the ground to fly up into the player, and the other summons daggers from either the left or right side of the arena. Since he can spam them, many times you'll be left without an opening to dodge through the attacks.

The second boss is really what takes the cake though because he can spawn minions who're also RNG reliant. Since they can all spawn projectiles to hit you with, you'll need to kill them else they'll turn the fight into a bullet hell. If you enter this fight as anything other than a shinobi or lich king, prepare for a frustrating battle.

With his remix fight though, you're in a world of pain. He spawns even more minions, the arena is covered in spikes, and with the zoomed in camera, you'll often teleport into enemies that you couldn't see. This is easily the most frustrating and difficult boss of the entire game. You can make it easier by spending money to buff the specter you play as for the fight, but ultimately this is a battle of luck. Please reconsider beating this game 100%.

3. [u] The Room Layouts. [/u]

The majority of them are really good actually, but a few can be packed to the brim with enemies. Overall it's not that bad. What is an issue though is walking into a room and immediately being hit by an enemy standing by the entrance because you couldn't react fast enough to not run into it. It happens rarely, but it happened enough to where I decided to put it here.

4. [u] The Hitboxes. [/u]

There seems to be a theme where the sprites of enemies, characters, and projectiles are larger than their hitboxes. It feels really weird having a spiked ball clearly touch your forehead only for it to phase right through you because your hitbox is actually shorter than your character sprite. The same goes for landing on platforms although I think this one is more an issue in that half the width of the character sprite is in the sword. It makes me think that my feet are more towards the center than they actually are.

5. [u] The Physics. [/u]

The most frustrating part of this game for me is how your character will go from no movement to full speed in a single frame. In a slower game like Castlevania this is perfectly fine, especially with how much of the screen you can see in that game, but in this game, coupled with the cameras zoom, the lack of any momentum makes everything feel so sudden. The same goes for enemies although since enemies take knockback it's generally not an issue.

Overall great game, but be prepared for the jank. It can definitely make you feel like the game has cheated you.
